title: 114_hr735
content: The "Cuba Reconciliation Act" removes provisions restricting trade and other relations with Cuba. The "Cuba Reconciliation Act" repeals authority for embargo under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and limits the President's authority under the Trading with the Enemy Act with respect to Cuba. It also removes export prohibitions to Cuba under the Export Administration Act of 1979. The Act repeals embargo authority under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and limits the President's authority under the Trading with the Enemy Act regarding Cuba. It also removes export prohibitions under the Export Administration Act of 1979. The President can impose new export controls on Cuba under certain sections of the Export Administration Act and exercise authorities under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act in case of a national emergency. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, removing restrictions on Cuba. Amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to reflect these changes. Amendments are made to various sections of different acts, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, lifting restrictions on Cuba. Amendments are made to various acts, including the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the Food Security Act of 1985. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is also amended to exclude Cuba from certain provisions. The government of a country makes amendments to the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000, excluding Cuba from certain provisions by striking sections 908, 909, and 910. Repeal of Prohibition on Transactions or Payments With Respect to Certain United States Intellectual Property under Section 211 of the Department of Commerce and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1999. SEC. 3 authorizes common carriers to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the US and Cuba, including upgrades. SEC. 4 pertains to travel. SEC. 4 allows for unrestricted travel to and from Cuba for US citizens and residents, including transactions related to travel. This includes normal banking transactions involving foreign currency. The United States Postal Service will establish direct mail service to and from Cuba, using charter providers if necessary. This Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment.
